D-81730 Miinchen, Germany Received 11 November 1996; received in revised form 24 January 1997; accepted 24 January 1997 Abstract New catalyst preparation methods which avoid the formation of waste water are desirable for environmental reasons, especially in the case of catalysts produced in amounts as large as those in the DeNOx sector. Thermal spreading has recently been applied in the preparation of titania-supported tungsten and molybdenum monolayer catalysts. In this paper we compare catalysts which are prepared via ball milling of mixtures of the individual precursor oxides with subsequent thermal spreading to catalysts which are prepared by a conventional coprecipitation process. Titania (anatase) was milled in the presence of either tungsten trioxide or molybdenum trioxide and these mixtures were subsequently calcined in a stream of oxygen which contained water vapor. After calcination, no crystalline WO3 or MoO3 was detected by XRD or DRIFTS, indicating a good dispersion of the active oxides, The overtones of tungsten and molybdenum oxygen double bond vibrations, which are representative for the formation of surface polyoxo compounds, were detected with DRIFT spectroscopy for samples prepared either by coprecipitation or via ball milling. The intensity distribution of the hydroxyl groups for ball mill prepared samples was different from the distribution for coprecipitated samples. When the physical mixtures were milled for several hours, the anatase was transformed into futile as shown by X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, a decrease in surface area and changes in the pore size distribution were observed in correlation with the milling. ~ 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Jentoft et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 161 (1997) 167-182 Impregnation and coprecipitation methods are the predominant preparation procedures for such cata- lysts. The adsorption of volatile precursors with sub- sequent hydrolysis has also been applied for their preparation. These preparation techniques involve large volumes of solutions and suspensions, resulting in waste water which must be disposed of. Thus, an alternative preparation route which avoids an aqueous medium is desirable. Solid-solid wetting has been investigated for sev- eral years as a new pathway for the formation of monolayer catalysts [9,10,18-23]. A recent review by Knfzinger and Taglauer [24] provides information on the theoretical background and a summary of experimental data. In brief, the method involves mix- ing of the support with the active oxides followed by a thermal treatment in an oxidizing environment, often in the presence of water vapor. It has been shown that the active (and mobile) oxides are not only dispersed (thermal spreading) by this technique but also converted into polyoxo compounds. Specifically, the spreading of MoO3 and WO3 and other oxides on different supports such as alumina, titania and silica has been investigated [9,10,15,18-20]. Both active oxides spread on alu- mina and titania when the mixtures of support and active oxide are calcined [ 18-20]. MoO3 was shown to spread on the anatase and the rutile modification of titania [22,25] and WO3 was found to spread on a commercial titania containing both phases [15,26]. The spreading occurs faster with increasing calcina- tion temperature [15]. The presence of water vapor accelerates the process and lowers the spreading tem- perature [15,27], it also leads to more homogeneous products with regard to the dispersion [27]. If water vapor is present during the calcination, the active oxides are transformed into surface polytungstate or polymolybdate species, which are characteristic of the conventionally prepared catalysts [19,20]. A mechanism via surface diffusion in a concentra- tion gradient or via gas phase transport has been excluded [18,19] since the spreading does not occur on silica. Surface (two-dimensional) melting was proposed to be important for the spreading process [24] which is consistent with the fact that the spread- ing temperatures can be correlated with the melting temperatures of the mobile oxides. The surface free energy was discussed as a driving force [21,23,24]. Smaller grain sizes of the mobile oxides showed a positive effect on the spreading process [24]. Hilbrig et al. [15] found that a high surface area WO3 spreads faster on titania than a low surface area WO3. Mestl [27], Leyrer [28] and Polz [29] calcined mixtures of MoO3 and alumina after previous milling and observed facilitated spreading. The surface area of MoO3 increased while it was milled [27], correspond- ing to a smaller particle size. The calcination of mobile oxide/support mixtures which were previously ground in a ball mill resulted in more homogeneous products as compared to samples obtained from unmilled mixtures. Additionally, the spreading took place at a 50 K lower temperature after the mixtures were milled [27]. The milling might not only affect the grain size, it is also known that solid state reactions can result from a tribochemical process [30]. However, the mechanism of the spreading process is not further understood, although positive effects of grinding or milling sam- ples prior to calcination have been demonstrated. Investigations on the use of ball milling in monolayer catalyst preparation have focused on the dispersion of the active oxide and on the formation of the surface polyoxo compound rather than effects on the support. Ball milling has also been applied by Zazhigalov et al. [31] in the preparation of a very different type of catalysts, namely V-P-O catalysts. Suspensions of catalyst powder in ethanol were milled which is being referred to as mechanochemical treatment. Changes in surface area, phase composition and catalytic activity were observed. Rtihle et al. [32] mechanically acti- vated iron oxide, resulting in a different activity and selectivity of the catalyst in Fischer-Tropsch synth- esis. In materials science, ball milling has raised interest as a new low-temperature preparation techni- que [33]. The scope of this work is to investigate; (i) the applicability of ball milling and subsequent thermal spreading to prepare well-defined titania-supported molybdenum and tungsten catalysts; (ii) the compar- ison of these materials with conventionally prepared samples, (using coprecipitation); (iii) the effect of the milling on the properties of the support, especially after a long period of milling. Results from vibrational spectroscopy are complemented by data from X-ray diffraction, surface area and pore size measure- ments. F.C. Preparation Catalyst powders prepared by a coprecipitation process from metatitanic acid and tungsten or molyb- denum salts, respectively, were provided by Siemens AG KWU KPW, Redwitz, Germany. The composi- tions of the catalysts were 10 wt% WO3]WiO2 with a sulfate content of 2.69 wt%, and 11 wt% MoO3/TiO2 with a sulfate content of 1.6 wt%, The following chemicals were used for the labora- tory preparations: TiO2-DT51 (Rhone-Poulenc, France), pure anatase, 97 m2/g, containing 1.15 wt% SO4- as a major impurity (others may be present at a very low level but were not analyzed); WO3 p.a. and MoO3 p.a. (both Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). The composition of the ball mill prepared samples was the same as in the industrial catalyst powders from copre- cipitation. Industrial catalyst powders are denoted TiW and TiMo. Physical mixtures are denoted WO3/TiO2 and MoO3frio2. The milling was performed in a planetary ball mill with an agate container having 300 cm3 volume and six 20 mm diameter agate balls with a weight of approximately 11 g each. The container spins around its own axis and around a second axis outside its center (140 revolutions). Typical initial loads were 15-25 g. Mixtures were stirred for 2 min in a beaker before the powder was placed into the container. The WO3/TiO2 and MoO3FFiO2 samples which were used for calcina- tion were milled for 1 h. Samples of typically 1.5 g were taken after 0.5, 1,2, 5 and 10 h from one batch to study the effect of the milling itself in more detail. Thus, the load of the mill decreased during the experi- ment. Calcination conditions were chosen to be the same as those for the industrial preparation. Tungsten oxide catalysts were calcined at 893 K for 7 h while molybdenum oxide catalysts were calcined 4 h at 823 K. Pure titania was calcined at both 893 K |br 7 h and at 823 K for 4 h. The pure titania and coprecipitated samples were calcined in air in a muffle furnace. The physical mixtures were calcined in a tubular quartz reactor in flowing oxygen. The partial pressure of water vapor was 32 mbar in a 50ml/min oxygen (99.995%, Linde, Germany) stream. X-ray diffraction was performed using a method described by Grbel [34] with a Siemens Guinier diffractometer using Cu K~ excitation (A--0.154 nm). The full widths at half maximum were determined by least-square-fits with Pseudo-Voigt-functions. DRIFT-spectra were recorded with a Bruker IFS 88 FTIR spectrometer, equipped with a Spectratech dif- fuse reflectance cell and an MCT detector. Samples were pretreated at 623 K for 1 h in a 25 ml/min flow of dry nitrogen. These same conditions were used for data acquisition. The accuracy of the temperature was limited by the position of the thermocouple to +20 K. The spectral resolution was 2 cm ~ and the number of scans was typically 1024. BET surface areas and pore size distributions were measured with a Carlo Erba (Fisons Instruments) Sorptomatic 1800. Samples were outgassed for 30 min at 5 10_2 mbar/473 K prior to the adsorption. 3. Anatase-rutile-phase transformation The brookit and anatase modifications of titania both transform into rutile, the most common form of titania, before they melt [35]. The anatase-rutile transformation is undesirable in the field of catalysis because it is usually accompanied by a severe decrease EC. Local heating effects have been proposed as a cause for the transformation [24]. Other authors [38] claim that the pressure on the material, produced by the balls in the mill, may be the dominating factor. This theory is supported by the observation of an intermediate, high-pressure modifi- cation of TiO2 [38]. The smaller average particle size achieved during the milling process may also affect the phase transition. Garvie [42] has inferred that the metastable tetragonal zirconia exists in a certain range of particle sizes where the surface free energy is lower compared to the stable monoclinic phase. This hypoth- esis may also be applicable to materials other than zirconia. The stability of the anatase is influenced by several parameters. The transition temperature was found to depend on the method of synthesis, the surrounding atmosphere, and the presence of foreign ions [43]. The latter are either intentionally added or impurities, and they can be in the bulk or on the surface. The transformation occurs for pure titania as well as for WO3/TiO2 and MoO3/TiO2 mixtures. At the same time, the anatase lines broaden during the milling process. Possible reasons for line broadening are (i) a decreasing particle size and (ii) an increase in lattice strain. Milling does not only affect the support but also EC. These results are consistent with observations by Hilbrig [15], who found an amorphization of WO3 when it was milled in a mixture with titania. The line broadening which is detected in the case of MoO3 has been attributed to smaller grain sizes by Mestl et al. [27], and not to strain in the crystals. Hence, through ball milling, anatase is trans- formed into rutile, and apparently the particle size of all components decreases. DRIFT-spectroscopy of titania-supported tungsten and molybdenum catalysts DRIFT-spectroscopy gives information on hydroxyl groups of the support, how they are affected when an active species is anchored to the surface, and on the structure of the surface active species itself. Titania has several absorptions in the hydroxyl regime. The literature data are neither consistent for anatase nor for rutile. In the case of anatase, mostly two bands at 3665-3675cm-L and ca. 3720- 3725 cm ~ are documented [53-56]. Additionally, bands at ca. 3640 cm-I [53,54] and 3715 cm-l are frequently reported [54,57]. Absorptions at 3735 [58], 3680-3690 [15,59,60], 3650-3660 [57,59,60] and 3410-3420cm-1 [57,59] have been assigned to rutile. The existence of W-OH and Mo-OH groups which terminate surface species have been discussed [13,16,17,61,62]. They are expected in the same fre- quency range as Ti-OH groups and, therefore, these species are difficult to distinguish from each other [16]. Absorptions which have increasing intensity with increasing molybdenum concentration have been interpreted as molybdenum hydroxyl groups [ 17]. The opposite effect, namely, a decreasing intensity of certain hydroxyls with increasing loading, was observed for tungsten trioxide supported on titania [ 15]. Hence, the bands were assigned to titania hydro- xyl groups. The overtone of the M=O (M---W, Mo) stretching mode in the range 1900-2100 cm-I is a probe for the formation of surface polyoxo compounds [2,16,17]. Anatase and WO3 do not have absorptions in the range 1800-2200 cm- l; the WO3 structure does not exhibit terminal tungsten oxygen bonds. The layer structure of MoO3 involves Mo=O units [63] which lead to bands at 1950, 1918 and 1879 cm-I with two shoulders at approx. 1993 and 1973 cm-1 (this work). The over- tone of the W=O stretching vibration of polytungstates on TiO2 surfaces is found at 2000-2008 cm- l [2]. An increasing tungsten loading causes a shift to increas- ing wave numbers (2008 cm-1) which is probably due to a higher degree of condensation. The position of the band is also sensitive to the presence of adsorbed water which shifts the band from 2020 to 1950 cm-I [16]. Similar observations are made for polymolybdates on titania [17]. In water vapor con- taining atmosphere, the Mo=O overtone is detected at 1900 cm- 1, and after evacuation at 673 K it is detected at 1985 cm i. A high loading gives MoO3-1ike fea- tures in the spectrum. 4.4. Effect of ball milling on surface area Pure titania shows a considerable loss of surface area while being milled (Fig. 6) which is consistent with the observed transformation into rutile (Fig. 1). But the anatase lines in the XRD pattern are broa- dened, indicating decreasing particle sizes, which should result in a larger surface area. Thus, two opposing effects are competing, and it is not easily possible to assign the individual contributions of anatase, rutile, and maybe an X-ray amorphous frac- tion to the total surface area of titania. Similarly, the surface areas of the mixtures are influenced by several factors, i.e., (i) transformation of the titania from anatase into rutile, (ii) smaller grain sizes of the remaining anatase fraction, and (iii) contributions of the active oxides. The diffraction patterns of WO3 and MoO3 disappear when the mixtures are milled for a long period of time. The effect is likely correlated to a decrease in particle size which would result in an increase in surface area. This interpretation is con- sistent with data reported by Mestl et al. [27], who milled pure MOO3. Mestl observed a steep increase in surface area up to ca. 30 m2/g after an induction period of approximately 1 h of milling. However, the effect of the milling on the surface areas of titania and the active oxides is small after only 1 h of milling, and a series of experiments would be required for a quantitative interpretation of the surface area of the mixtures. 4.6. Effect of ball milling on pore size distribution The prominent peak at 40 ,~ in the pore size dis- tribution of titania (Fig. 7(a)) disappears completely after 25 h of milling (Fig. 7(d)). The pore size dis- tributions of the WO3/TiO2 (Fig. 8(a)) and MOO3/ TiO2 mixtures are strongly perturbed already after 1 h of milling, as compared to the pore size distribu- tion of pure titania (Fig. 7(a)) which is representative for the unmilled mixtures. Since the promoter oxides do not significantly contribute to the pores, the pore size distribution mirrors the titania fraction of the sample. In a simple model, pores are formed by agglomerates of crystals which have an interstitial space that corresponds to the pore size distribution. The milling obviously affects the structure of these agglomerates. The changes of the pore structure are not accompanied by a change of surface area as long as the milling time is short, and a measurable formation of rutile has not yet occurred. A possible explanation within the simple model presented could be that the agglomerates which form the pores are broken into their parts, i.e., crystallites. A similar conclusion was drawn by Mestl et al. (1995a) in [27] from data which were obtained after the milling of MOO3, i.e., initially the agglomerates are affected and not the crystallites, 4. 7. Effect of calcination on support structure and morphology The calcination temperatures are below values at which an anatase-rutile transformation occurs with a considerable rate; and stabilizing sulfate is present, at least prior to calcination (vide infra). Thus, changes in the phase composition of the titania as a result of calcination are not expected. The XRD data obtained after calcination of titania samples, the 1 h ball milled WO3/TiO2 and MoO3/TiO2 mixtures, and the copre- cipitated samples, are consistent with this expectation; no rutile is detected. The absence of rutile in the calcined ball milled mixtures might be an indication that after 1 h of milling no ruffle had formed since nuclei would be expected to grow during calcination and then become detectable. The line narrowing, which is observed after calci- nation for all samples, namely pure titania, ball mill and conventionally prepared samples, indicates recrystallization of the anatase support. It is known from electron microscopy of pure titania [64] that the anatase surface is smoothened during calcination. The grain surfaces are rough before calcination, and char- acterized by 5-35 ,~ microfacet ledges. After calcina- tion, larger facet planes of approx. 120-210 ,~ are observed. The average grain size after calcination is 30-50 ,~ as compared to 20-30 A before calcination [64]. The much smoother surface explains the decrease of surface strain, leading to narrower lines in the diffractograms. The smooth surface and larger grains also account for the loss of surface area observed in titania (Table 3). The particle growth could be related to the formation of larger pores (Fig. 7(a)-(c)) during calcination. Agglomerates formed out of larger particles would naturally have a larger interstitial space. The tendency to form larger E C. Jentoft et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 161 (1997) 167-182 179 pores with increasing temperature has also been described for zirconia [65]. The shift towards larger pores increases with calcination temperature and dura- tion, which is consistent with the line narrowing observed in the diffractograms (Table 1) and with decreasing surface area (Table 3). The anatase lines of the calcined coprecipitated samples, namely TiW and TiMo, are broader than those of pure titania (Table 1). The presence of tung- state or molybdate, may result in a lower mobility of surface atoms as discussed for the presence of sulfate or phosphate groups. TEM pictures support this hypothesis by showing that the ragged surface of pure titania becomes smooth during calcination, while the disordered surface structure is conserved when titania- supported tungstate samples prepared from copreci- pitation are calcined I64]. The observation corre- sponds to the fact that line widths and surface areas undergo smaller changes during calcination in the presence of tungstate and molybdate (i.e., samples TiW and TiMo) on the surface as compared to pure titania. A volatilization of sulfate, tungstate, or molyb- date is not observed below 973 K for TiW and TiMo by DTG/TG-MS. However, the analysis of TiW after calcination for 7 h at 893 K gives a sulfate content of only 0.69 wt. These results are not necessarily con- tradictory since in the thermoanalytical experiment the sample was heated with a higher rate than during calcination and was kept at a high temperature for a shorter time than during calcination. The differences in line widths and surface area between the calcined TiW and TiMo samples arise from the different calci- nation conditions. Higher temperature and longer duration result in narrower lines for TiW than for TiMo, these results are consistent with what is observed for pure titania. Water vapor which was present during calcination of the ball milled mixtures is known to influence the sintering rate. The sintering rates of titania [66], zirconia [67] and alumina [68] increase in the presence of water vapor. On the other hand, fast spreading of WO3 and MoO3 with formation of a surface species could prevent sintering by reducing the mobility of surface atoms as described above. The surface area loss of the mixtures is higher than that of titania and the coprecipitated samples when calcined under the same conditions (Table 3); thus, the recrystallization has to proceed with a higher rate than the spreading. Consistently, electron microscopy data show a reason- able dispersion for ball milled WO3/TiO2 mixtures only after 9 h of calcination [64]. The pore size distribution, which is altered by the milling process, does not change considerably during the thermal treatment. Hence, the catalysts from ball mill preparation and coprecipitation differ signifi- cantly in their pore size distribution. While the sam- ples from coprecipitation are characterized by a defined maximum the ball mill prepared systems lack prominent features. 4.8.
